Could be improved if the bubble had two "sensitivity" settings.  I used a standard 24 inch framing level to find a a completely level place on my concrete floor to calibrate both my phone and the app.  This app has the bubble move through 360 degrees of angle, while a framing  level only provides meaningful reading for about 2 degrees on either side of the angle, a range of about 5 degrees, so when you are close to level the bubble does not add value with this app, but the readings do.  Though on my phone even when sitting on  a concrete floor the readings would flicker between a couple of tenths of a degree. I suspect this is a hardware (phone) issue not a software (app) issue.  Also the app works without being online, and does not have ads.

Great app that will be super handy in the field, esp with the readout showing 1/10 of a degree accuracy.  I don't mean to flame the "Calibration whiners", but come on. If you live in even a semi-new home just lay the thing on the bathroom counter to calibrate it (as one person already pointed out, most professional installed surfaces are already level.) If you just want to hang pictures here is a tip.. calibrate it by using the wall... if the wall is crooked and your pictures straight then it will show. :] Meanwhile, you should only have to calibrate it once.  I also suspect that people who yell that it is way off just have bad sensors because the app is solid!

title: A Calibration Hint
comment: First of all this is a great App.  Just as accurate as the torpedo level that bangs around in my tool box for rough work where precision accuracy is not needed (like hanging pictures).    Most handy of all is that it is always with me...unlike any "store bought" level.  Now the hint...You do NOT need another level to calibrate it.  Step 1:  Find an adjustable, nearly level, hard surface where you can view both the front AND back of the phone.  (examples might be a hardcover book on a coffee table or even the coffee table itself if you can "shim" the legs to level)  Step 2: (not necessary but advised):  Purposely calibrate your level OUT OF LEVEL by 1 to 5 degrees  Step 3:  On your surface, use the app to record the level in one direction.  Memorize the reading  (ie: 1.6 degrees to the left).  Step 4:  Rotate the phone 180 degrees and take another reading (this is why you had to pick a surface where you could view both sides of a phone in step one)  IF THE TWO READINGS ARE THE SAME BUT IN OPPOSITE DIRECTIONS, THE SURFACE IS LEVEL.  If not the same, shim the surface and repeat the process until the readings are the same.   Step 5:  Calibrate your phone on the now level surface
